title: JDemetra+ Universe
text: This blog is dedicated to promoting JDemetra+ software and spreading information across the users community.

title: Talks about JD+ at ISI world statistics congress
text:
Two talks around JDemetra+ were given at the 64th ISI World Statistics Congress held in Ottawa, Canada.

JDemetra+ 3.0: a versatile time series analysis software (Anna Smyk and Tanguy Barthelemy, Insee, France)
Efficient nowcasting tools based on mixed-frequency state space models(Jean Palate and Corentin Lemasson, NBB)

You can find the abstracts and the full program on the conference website https://www.isi2023.org/

title: Upcoming Talks about JD+ at NTTS 2023 conference
text:
NTTS 2023 conference will host a Time Series analysis session chaired by Jean Palate (NBB, Belgium) on Thursday 9th at 16:00, with two talks around JDemetra+:

Fixing the model for the seasonal component: a new revision policy, by Maria Novas Filgueira (INE, Spain) and al.
JDemetra+ 3.0: New (R) tools for (high-frequency) time series analysis, by Tanguy Barthelemy and Anna Smyk (Insee, France)

You can browse the complete agenda here

title: NTTS 2025…and JDemetra+
text:
The NTTS 2025 conference is just a few weeks away! A unique venue for the statistical community….
You can access the draft program here.
I will be chairing a session on Time Series analysis on Thursday March 13th at 2:30 pm, with talks around JDemetra+:



TSA Session Talks

title: Time Series Analysis Workshop
text:
A Workshop on Time Series Analysis and Statistical Disclosure Control Methods for Official Statistics will be held at OECD, Boulogne (Paris), France on December 14th and 15th 2023.
Several talks relate to JDemetra+.
The full program is available here here
To attend (in presence or remotely), please register here.
https://forms.office.com/e/3c817rYFjd

title: OECD 2023 TSA Workshop: 3 talks about JD+
text:
Three talks about JDemetra+ were delivered at the Workshop on Time Series Analysis and Statistical Disclosure Control Methods for Official Statistics, held at OECD, Boulogne (Paris), France on December 14th and 15th 2023.
Presentations available below:

Introducing the potential of rjd3sts, the R tool from JDemetra+ dedicated to State Space models, with some case studies, by Corentin Lemasson (National Bank of Belgium).
R-package tvCoef, implementing time-varying coefficients models has never been so easy, by Alain Quartier-la-Tente (Insee)
JDemetra+: from version 2 to version 3 how has the software evolved?, by Anna Smyk (Insee)

title: Time Series Analysis Workshop
text:
A Workshop on Time Series Analysis will be held at OECD, Paris, La Muette, France on December 5th and 6th 2024.
The two main topics are Nowcasting and Seasonal Adjustment.
Several talks relate to JDemetra+.
The full program is available here
To attend (in presence or remotely), register using this link
https://forms.office.com/e/EtivNwehxc
Note that all meeting documents will be posted on: https://one-communities.oecd.org/community/workshop-on-time-series-methods-for-official-statistics/SitePages/Home.aspx
For any questions regarding logistics, please contact virginie.elgrably@oecd.org

title: TSA Workshop: presentations
text:
A very engaging 4th Edition of the Time Series Analysis for Official Statistics Workshop took place at OECD, Paris, La Muette, France on December 5th and 6th 2024 and via Zoom.
The two main topics were Nowcasting and Seasonal Adjustment and several talks were related to JDemetra+.
The full program is available here and all the presenations at: https://one-communities.oecd.org/community/workshop-on-time-series-methods-for-official-statistics/SitePages/Home.aspx
We were delighted to spend time with some of you ! Very fruitful discussions and good mood, thank you for attending.
See you next year !

title: Upcoming Talks about JD+ at uRos 2022 conference
text:
The use of JDemetra+ algorithms in R will be highlighted in two talks. Find out more…

R and JDemetra+ 3.0 a new toolbox around seasonal adjustment and time series analysis, by Alain Quartier-la-tente, Insee, France. (Tuesday Dec 6th, 17:00 CET)
Towards Seasonal Adjustment of Infra-Monthly Time Series with JDemetra+ 3.0 and rjd3highfreq R package, by Anna Smyk, Insee, France. (Tuesday Dec 6th, 17:15 CET)

Please find the complete agenda and Zoom link here.

title: Tutorial on rjdverse packages at uRos 2024
text:
The 2024 edition of uRos (Use of R in Official Statistics) conference was held in Athens, Greece on November 27th to 29th.
We gave a tutorial about (some) of the packages of the rjdverse family, it is available here.
We also presented a poster which is currently travelling on its own through Europe.

title: New discussion paper
text:
New discussion paper: Towards seasonal adjustment of infra-monthly time series with JDemetra+ by Karsten Webel (BBk) and Anna Smyk (Insee)
JDemetra+ has been recently augmented with algorithms tailored to the specifics of infra-monthly data and accessible through an ecosystem of R packages (rjd3highfreq, rjd3x11plus, rjd3stl). We give a comprehensive overview of the packages’ current developmental stage and illustrate selected capabilities, including code snippets, using daily births in France, hourly electricity consumption in Germany, and weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance in the United States, adjusted with structural models (rjd3sts).
Read the full paper here

title: Discussion Paper on revisions in daily and weekly series
text:
A new Bundesbank Discussion Paper is just out: Revisions in concurrent seasonal adjustments of daily and weekly economic time series by Karsten Webel (Deutsche Bundesbank)
Abstract
The COVID-19 outbreak in 2020 has fostered in many countries the development of new weekly economic indices for the timely tracking of pandemic-related turmoils and other forms of rapid economic changes. Such indices often utilise information from daily and weekly economic time series that normally exhibit complex forms of seasonal behaviour. The latter dynamics were initially removed with ad hoc or experimental methods due to the urgent need of instant results and hence the lack of time for inventing and approving more sophisticated alternatives. This, never- theless, has in turn inspired recent developments of seasonal adjustment methods tailored to the specifics of infra-monthly time series. Although sound theoretical descriptions of these tailored methods are already available, their performance has not been evaluated empirically in great detail so far. To fill this gap, we consider real-time data vintages of several infra-monthly economic time series for Germany and analyse the cross-vintage stability of holiday-related deterministic pretreatment effects as well as the revisions in various concurrent signal estimates obtained with experimental STL-based and selected elaborate methods, such as the extended ARIMA model-based and X-11 approaches. Our main findings are that the tai- lored methods tend to outperform the experimental ones in terms of computational speed, that the considered pretreatment routines yield generally stable parameter es- timates across data vintages, and that the extended ARIMA model-based approach generates the smallest and least volatile revisions in many cases.
Read the full paper here

title: JDemetra+ New online documentation
text: First release of the new (revamped) JDemetra+ on-line documentation today ! You can explore the new website, featuring, among other things, up-to-date (though partial) information on using JDemetra+ in R and seasonal adjustment of high frequency data. It is far from being complete, but we hope it will grow fast from here ! Feel free to post issues in the corresponding GitHub repository and give us some feedback by commenting this post. (To post comments you have to be connected to GitHub)

title: JDemetra+ New online documentation
text:
JDemetra+ on-line documentation keeps growing. The new website has up-to-date* information on using JDemetra+ in R and seasonal adjustment of high frequency data. Chapters on seasonal adjustment and calendar correction have been significantly improved. It is a work in progress…
*: all information might not be exactly up-to-date as the recent change in package structure is concerned. But should be very soon. (rjd3toolkit, rjd3modelling, rjd3arima, rjd3sa were merged into one rjd3toolkit package)
Feel free to post issues in the corresponding GitHub repository and give us some feedback by commenting this post. (To post comments you have to be connected to GitHub)

title: JDemetra+ v 3.5.0, Incubator v2.3.0 and R Packages v3.5.0
text:
Latest official version of JDemetra+ Graphical User Interface and Cruncher, released on April 9th 2025, can be found at
https://github.com/jdemetra/jdplus-main/releases/tag/v3.5.0
A new version of the incubator (v3.2.0) is also available
It contains, among other things, extensions of SA algorithms for High-Frequency data
More information at https://github.com/jdemetra/jdplus-incubator/releases/tag/v2.3.0
For installing instructions see https://jdemetra-new-documentation.netlify.app/#installing-the-software
A new release of rjd3toolkit, rjd3tramoseats, rjd3x13, rjd3sts, rjd3providers, rjd3workspace has just been published
All rjdverse packages are available on GitHub (https://github.com/rjdverse) and on r-universe (https://rjdverse.r-universe.dev/packages)
Installation procedures are detailed in the readme files.
Most of the other packages have also a significantly improved development version and will be released shortly.

title: Release of GUI and Cruncher v 3.2.4
text:
Latest official version of JDemetra+ can be found at
https://github.com/jdemetra/jdplus-main/releases/tag/v3.2.4
For installing instructions see https://jdemetra-new-documentation.netlify.app/#installing-the-software
Note that Java 17 is now embedded is in the installation files, you don’t need to tackle this issue on your computer. Be sure to choose the windows specific zip file (if you use windows).

title: Release of GUI and Cruncher v 3.2.2
text:
To get the latest official version of JDemetra+
Head over to https://github.com/jdemetra/jdplus-main/releases/tag/v3.2.2
If you use windows download this zip file: jdemetra-standalone-3.2.2-windows-x86_64.zip
Note that Java 21 is now embedded is in the installation files, you don’t need to tackle this issue on your computer.
For installing instructions go here.
In addition to main Graphical user interface (X13-Arima and Tramo-Seats), there is also a new version of
the cruncher, which can be installed downloading this zip jwsacruncher-3.2.2.zip.

title: Release of HF, STL+, STS, X12+ plug-ins v2.1.0
text:
A new version JDemetra+ additional SA algorithms is available.
In addition to the main Graphical user interface (X13-Arima and Tramo-Seats) recent release ( v3.2.2, see previous blog post), a new version (2.1.0) of the incubator has just been published.
The plug-ins contained in the incubator give access to STL+, STS, X12+ and extensions for high-frequency data.
Just download the following files and proceed with installation as described here

title: New version of R packages
text:
New version of RJDemetra and rjd3 packages available
The latest version (0.2.2) of RJDemetra can be found here:
https://github.com/jdemetra/rjdemetra/releases/tag/v0.2.2 and also on CRAN.
The latest version (3.0.0) of all the rjd3 packages can be found at

https://github.com/palatej/rjd3toolkit
https://github.com/palatej/rjd3x13
https://github.com/palatej/rjd3tramoseats

….
It contains a (heavily) updated documentation and (a lot of) bug fixes.

title: JOS Special Issue on Time Series Analysis in Official Statistics
text:
Journal of Official Statistics Special Issue on Time Series Analysis is just out and available here
Two papers are related to JDemetra+ algorithms

Seasonal adjustment of infra-monthly time series with JDemetra+ by Karsten Webel (BBk) and Anna Smyk (Insee)
Improving Real-Time Trend Estimates Using Local Parametrization of Polynomial Regression Filters by Alain quartier-La-Tente (Insee)

title: Major update in rjd3 packages suite
text:
In January 2023, the following four packages : rjd3toolkit, rjd3modelling, rjd3arima, rjd3sa were merged into one extended rjd3toolkit package.
The available tools are the same, but a significant number of functions were renamed.
The code from the webinar, available here, will work if you kept he older versions or install the older versions as explained on this same page.
An updated version will be available soon, we will keep you posted.
The videos from the webinar are no longer available on GitHub but can be watched on our YouTube Channel

title: Webinar on R tools for JDemetra+ from v2 to v3

title: Welcome To JDemetra+ Universe Blog
text: Now JDemetra+, a versatile time series analysis software recommended by Eurostat, has it’s blog !
